College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwest Normal University People’s Republic of Lanzhou 730070 China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Hydrogen production by water electrolysis is a convenient, low-energy and simple process. The generation of hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) through water electrolysis is a sustainable option for future clean energy, but it still faces challenges. A large number of gas bubbles are constantly generated during the hydrogen production process. These bubbles easily adhere to the surface of the material and cannot be detached from the surface quickly enough in time. Over time, the accumulation of bubbles relentlessly obscures a large number of otherwise active catalytic sites, severely hindering the mass-transfer process of reactants and products and leading to a dramatic decrease in mass-transfer efficiency. This leads to a significant reduction in the hydrogen production efficiency, which in turn reduces the overall efficiency of water decomposition. Therefore, the design and preparation of electrocatalysts with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobicity is one of the techniques to improve droplet wettability and reduce bubble attachment. Due to the ability of the superhydrophilic droplets to spread and penetrate rapidly on the electrode surface, Moreover, the superhydrophobicity greatly reduces the adhesion of gas bubbles on the electrode surface. As a result, the mass transfer and reaction kinetics involved in the hydrogen exclusion reaction (HER) and oxygen exclusion reaction (OER) were significantly optimized, which in turn enhanced the catalytic process of the oxygen exclusion reaction/hydrogen exclusion reaction. This paper reviews the reaction mechanisms of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic electrocatalysts, as well as the mechanisms of hydrogen and oxygen precipitation. Special attention is given to various preparation strategies for bimetallic nickel-iron based (NiFe-based) electrocatalysts and the application of heteroatom doping, heterostructures and oxygen vacancies in NiFe-based electrocatalysts. In addition, this review discusses the practical applications of other monometallic, bimetallic, and multimetallic electrocatalysts in the field of efficient electrocatalysis, as well as the challenges and future prospects. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Superhydrophilic/superaerophobic NiFe-based Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Water splitting Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the continuous development of society and the growth of population, the demand for energy has increased dramatically. Coping with the energy crisis is one of the most important problems that need to be solved in modern society [1,2]. Due to the excessive use of fossil fuels by human beings [3], our living environment has suffered serious and irreversible damages and impacts. There is an urgent need to develop clean, efficient, sustainable and renewable energy sources to replace fossil fuels. However, this is still a major challenge for mankind. Compared with fossil fuels such as coal, oil and natural gas [4], hydrogen energy has the advantages of zero pollution, high energy density, easy operation, low energy consumption and high efficiency. Therefore, vigorously developing hydrogen energy is an inevitable way to promote the energy revolution. However, it is not easy to obtain hydrogen naturally. Currently, the industrial method to obtain hydrogen is natural gas steam reforming [5], which is the cheapest and fastest way. However, a faster and simpler way to produce hydrogen is through electrochemical water decomposition. Water decomposition consists of two half-reactions: hydrogen-removal reaction (HER) and oxygen-removal reaction (OER). The hydrogenolysis reaction is a relatively simple process, whereas the oxygenolysis reaction is a multi-electron reaction that results in a kinetic delay.When a potential higher than the predicted equilibrium potential is applied, the OER process can be observed. This excess overpotential (η) makes water splitting an energy-intensive process. Commercial electrocatalysts for OER are noble metal-based materials (such as IrO2, RuO2, etc.) [6]. Due to their scarcity and high costs, the widespread application of noble metal-based catalysts is severely limited. Therefore, the exploration of low-cost and high-activity electrocatalysts has been a continuous endeavor. Electrocatalysts based on 3d transition metals have been widely reported due to their abundant reserves and high intrinsic activity. The electrocatalyst NiFe LDH has attracted extensive research due to its impressive advantages such as high specific surface area, adjustable chemical composition, and abundant surface active sites. Its activity is enhanced through a charge transfer activation mechanism at the Ni and Fe metal centers. Reducing the adsorption energy of hydrogen and oxygen-containing intermediates and facilitating the mass transfer of OH−/O2/H2 are two important factors for improving electrocatalytic performance. There is a very significant synergistic effect between nickel and iron atoms in NiFe LDH. However, the adsorption capacity of NiFe LDH electrocatalysts for the intermediates of the OER is relatively weak. This can be addressed by generating tensile strain to reduce the antibonding filling state of the d-orbitals [7] and adjusting the electronic structure through doping with heteroatoms. During the overall water splitting process in electrocatalysis, a large number of bubbles are generated, which significantly hinder electrocatalytic performance. By doping with heteroatoms, forming heterostructures, and introducing oxygen vacancies, the roughness of the electrocatalyst surface is increased and expose more active sites. This improves the wettability of droplets on the electrode surface and facilitates the detachment of bubbles from the electrode surface, thereby endowing the electrocatalyst with superhydrophilic/superaerophobic properties. In view of the excellent electrocatalytic properties and wide range of applications of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic electrocatalysts, it is necessary to provide a comprehensive review of their properties and applications. This review can inspire readers to discover the patterns. At the same time, it can also stimulate readers to generate more ideas in designing high-performance electrocatalysts. This electrocatalyst possesses a large number of active sites, which facilitates the rapid detachment of gas bubbles from the electrode surface as well as the wetting of the surface, thus enhancing the performance of the hydrogen-extraction reaction (HER) and oxygen-extraction reaction (OER). The summarized schematic of the superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic electrocatalyst for hydrogen and oxygen precipitation reactions is shown in Scheme 1 . 1.1 Reaction mechanism on the surface of superhydrophilic/superaerophobic electrocatalysts In recent years, studies on electrocatalysts for total water decomposition have focused on improving the catalytic efficiency through coordination environments, material compositions and electronic structures. However, the construction of catalytic interfaces that facilitate hydrogen- and oxygen-removal reactions and the modulation of the mass-transfer behavior of bubbles are equally important for water decomposition [8]. The HER and OER occur at the interface of the gas, liquid, and solid phases [9]. During the water splitting process, a large number of bubbles are generated on the electrode surface. If these bubbles cannot detach from the electrode surface in a timely manner, they will accumulate and block a significant number of active sites on the electrode surface, leading to the "bubble shielding effect" [10], which reduces the electrochemical reaction rate. Therefore, exploring and constructing electrocatalysts with superhydrophilic/superaerophobic properties is of great significance for the timely detachment of bubbles, reducing the adhesion of bubbles on the electrode material surface, expanding the active sites on the surface, and improving the electrical conductivity of the catalyst [11]. The hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity of the electrode surface, i.e., the wettability of the material surface [12,13], is a crucial characteristic when a solid surface comes into contact with a liquid. It plays a particularly important role in engineering applications involving numerous transport phenomena, typically occurring at interfaces, such as phase separation, drying, boiling, condensation, and adsorption [14–16]. By altering the wettability of the material surface, the contact behavior between the material surface and bubbles formed in water can be changed [17]. The surface of superhydrophilic/superaerophobic electrocatalysts is discontinuous compared to other material surfaces, allowing bubbles formed underwater to detach from the electrode surface in a timely manner. When the bubbles formed on the electrode surface are relatively small, they are easier to separate from the surface, thereby reducing the adhesion between the material surface and the formed bubbles and enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of the material. Wettability is closely related to the surface of the material. The surface where a liquid meets a solid is known as an interface. Surface tension/interfacial tension occurs when the forces acting on the interface are not uniform and cohesive forces are not balanced [18–20]. Wetting occurs when a liquid is in contact with a solid surface. According to Young's equation [21,22], as shown in Eq. (1), if the surface tension of the liquid (γL) is less than that of the solid (γS), the liquid will spread on the solid surface, which is referred to as the wetting process. On the contrary, if the surface tension of the liquid (γL) is greater than the surface tension of the solid (γS), the liquid will contract on the solid surface, which is known as the non-wetting process. The wettability of a liquid on a solid surface can be quantitatively described by the contact angle θ [23,24]. The contact angle is a common method to characterize and measure the macroscopic wettability of a surface, but it can also be used to show and determine the physical properties or chemical structure of a solid surface, such as interfacial tension. A simple thermodynamic interpretation of the contact angle can be given based on the force equilibrium of the interfacial tension, as shown in Fig. 1 . The contact angle of a droplet at equilibrium on a solid surface can be described by Young's equation. (1) γ S V = γ S L + γ L V c o s θ e In this equation, γSV, γSL, and γLV denote the solid-gas, solid-liquid, and liquid-gas interfacial tensions (in mN/m), respectively, and θe is the Young's contact angle at equilibrium (in degrees). In the literature, the liquid-gas interfacial tension γLV is often abbreviated to surface tension σ. It is worth noting that Young's equation is not a universal formula. Its application is limited to smooth, perfectly horizontal, ideal solid surfaces of uniform surface composition, non-deformable and free of any impurities, where the contact angle is referred to as the intrinsic contact angle. In practice, such a condition is difficult to realize. The equilibrium contact angle θe is jointly determined by the surface tension of the gas, liquid and solid phases. When the liquid and solid surfaces remain constant, the corresponding θe will also remain constant. However, after continuous exploration by researchers, it has been found that varying the roughness of a solid surface can significantly change θe. This is because, as mentioned above, Young's equation applies to ideal conditions, which do not apply to most rough solid surfaces with inhomogeneous surface compositions. This limits the practical application of Young's equation. Based on the Young's equation model, researchers proposed the Wenzel [25,26] and Cassie [27] models. Through continuous research and exploration, Wenzel discovered that most solid surfaces are inhomogeneous, rough, not perfectly horizontal, and highly textured. When a liquid droplet is placed on a rough solid surface, the actual contact angle is difficult to measure and is referred to as the apparent contact angle. The actual surface of the solid is uneven, with numerous groove structures distributed across it. When a liquid droplet lands on the solid surface, these droplets fully penetrate and fill these grooves. Compared to a smooth solid surface, the contact area between the droplet and the rough solid surface increases significantly. Building upon Young's equation, Wenzel further explored how enhancing the roughness of the solid surface could improve wettability. He proposed a new equation, as shown in Eq. (2), elucidating how an increase in surface area can lead to superhydrophobic phenomena on the surface. (2) c o s γ W = r c o s γ Y In this equation, γW denotes the apparent contact angle and γY denotes the intrinsic or Young's contact angle. r is the roughness factor, which represents the ratio of the true area of a rough surface to the area of a correspondingly smooth surface prior to roughness. The Wenzel equation shows that as the roughness of a solid surface increases, the hydrophilicity or hydrophobicity of the surface becomes more pronounced. However, it is difficult to obtain a value for r for actual rough surfaces. Wenzel's equation is only applicable to explain phenomena where the droplet size is negligible in relation to the rough solid surface structure. Wenzel and Baxter further modified Young's equation by recognizing that when a liquid actually comes into contact with a solid surface, the droplets may not fill the entire groove structure of the surface. The air trapped in them may not completely detach from the solid surface, but instead remain in the groove, forming a cushion of air. This prevents the droplet from making maximum contact with the groove interface structure and reduces the wettability. Compared to the Wentzel model, the sliding angle and contact angle hysteresis of the liquid are relatively small, allowing for superhydrophobicity. This is represented by the following Eq. (3). (3) c o s θ 0 = f 1 · ( c o s θ + 1 ) − 1 In this equation, f1 represents the ratio of the area of contact between the droplet and the solid to the total contact area. As shown in Fig. 1 [28], from a microscopic perspective, the contact angle of water on a solid surface can reflect the interaction at the solid-water interface. When the contact angle θ between the droplet and the solid surface is <90°, the solid surface can be wetted by the liquid, and such a surface is defined as hydrophilic. When the contact angle is close to θ<10°, the solid surface is defined as superhydrophilic, where the droplet completely spreads out on the surface. When the contact angle θ between the droplet and the solid surface is greater than 90°, the solid surface cannot be wetted by the liquid, and the droplet on the solid surface will exhibit a phenomenon of shrinking into a sphere. Such a surface is defined as hydrophobic. When the contact angle θ exceeds 150°, the solid surface is defined as superhydrophobic, where the droplet on the surface is completely compacted. The smaller the contact angle value, the stronger the interaction between the water and the solid, leading to partial or complete wetting (hydrophilic or superhydrophilic). In this case, the hydrophilic surface tends to attract neighboring water molecules with forces greater than the attraction between water molecules in the native water. Inspired by the micro-hierarchical structure of superhydrophobic lotus leaf surfaces, artificial roughnesses designed using micro/nanostructures have been used to prepare superhydrophilic and superhydrophobic surfaces, corresponding to nearly fully wetted and fully unwetted states, respectively. The above non-ideal surface models provide guidance for the construction and development of artificial heterogeneous surfaces. Actual solid surfaces often deviate from the ideal state described by Young's equation and may exhibit roughness, inhomogeneity and anisotropy characteristics due to processing or exposure to the surrounding environment. Electrode surface roughness has a significant effect on the desorption behavior of bubbles from water [29]. Using a microbalance camera system, the researchers investigated the effect of nanoscale (random) roughness of the surface (characterized by root-mean-square roughness RMS in the range of about 3–260 nm) on the strength of adhesion of bubbles to the naturally hydrophilic hematite and pyrite surfaces. Based on fundamental studies in mineral froth flotation, there is ample evidence available that the interaction between bubbles and solids is modulated by the chemical and physical properties of the interfacial surfaces. In this study, two hydrophilic natural mineral samples, hematite (Fe2O3) and pyrite (FeS2), were selected, which are chemically different but show similar hydrophilicity in terms of contact angle (66±3° for hematite and 58±2° for pyrite). Fresh surfaces with different nanoscale roughness characteristics (RMS = 3–260 nm) were prepared by a multi-stage polishing process for both samples, and the surfaces were imaged and quantitatively analyzed using atomic force microscopy (AFM). Subsequently, the interaction forces between the bubbles and the mineral surface in water during attachment, spreading, adhesion and detachment were measured by microbalance. The results confirm that the interaction of hydrophilic minerals with water is enhanced with the increase of their nanoscale surface roughness, but this is at the expense of weakening their interaction with air bubbles. The adhesion force of both minerals was reported to be linearly correlated with the root mean square (RMS) roughness. Furthermore, the experimental adhesion force was linearly related to the contact angle and its sinusoidal function, indicating that the three-phase contact line is closely related to the roughness distribution of the hydrophilic solids and that the surface tension dominates the adhesion behavior of bubbles in water to hydrophilic surfaces. The results confirm that the adhesion to bubbles is weakened by hydrophilic surfaces with nanoscale roughness. The mechanism by which surface roughness influences the separation forces between bubbles and glass beads with different contact angles through flotation is shown in Fig. 2 [30]. When the contact angle is <90°, the wetting state can be described by the Wenzel model: on the one hand, the apparent contact angle decreases; on the other hand, the presence of water vesicles along the contact line shortens the effective length of the three-phase contact line. As a result, the capillary forces between the bubbles and the particles are weakened, leading to a lower separation force. However, for rough solid surfaces with contact angles > 90°, the wetting state can be described by the Cassie model: the apparent contact angle and the length of the contact line increase, which explains the increased separation force for hydrophobic particles. The effect of surface roughness on the separation between bubbles and glass beads at different contact angles was investigated using a home-made bubble-particle separation measurement system. The results showed that when the local contact angle with the particle surface was lower than 90° (indicating hydrophilicity), the separation force of smooth particles was higher than that of rough particles. However, when the local contact angle with the particle surface was greater than 90° (indicating hydrophobicity), the separation force of rough particles was higher than that of smooth particles. Surface roughness resulted in a decrease in the stability of hydrophilic bubble particle aggregates and an increase in the stability of hydrophobic bubble particle aggregates. Decrease in apparent contact angle and contact line length decreases the separation force of hydrophilic particles, while increase in these parameters enhances the separation force of hydrophobic particles. 1.1.1 Basic principles of electrocatalytic water splitting Electrocatalytic water decomposition technology consists of two components: hydrogen-removal reaction (HER) and oxygen-removal reaction (OER). A water decomposition electrolysis cell usually consists of an electrolyte, a diaphragm, a cathode and an anode [31]. HER and OER occur almost simultaneously at the cathode and anode, respectively, where water molecules produce H2 and O2, respectively. These reactions can be carried out in different pH media through different pathways [32]. The main challenge is to overcome the energy barriers at each step of the reaction process. Theoretically, the thermodynamic potential for electrocatalyzed water decomposition is 1.23 V (relative to the reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) [33]. However, in practice there is always an overpotential, which leads to the need for higher cell voltages and more energy consumption to realize the full hydrolysis reaction. In order to lower the energy barrier, suitable electrocatalysts need to be introduced to reduce the overpotential of HER and OER. 1.1.1.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) In acidic solutions, hydrogen precipitation reactions (HER) can proceed by two mechanisms.The catalytic activity of HER is related to the free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔGH*) [34]. The first step is the Volmer reaction: electrons flowing through the circuit combine with protons in solution to form hydrogen atoms in the adsorbed state at the active sites on the electrode surface [35]. In the second step, when the hydrogen content adsorbed on the electrode surface is low, these hydrogen atoms tend to undergo the Heyrovsky reaction [36], combining with new electrons and protons in solution, releasing hydrogen; if the electrode surface has a high hydrogen content, the Tafel reaction is more likely to occur [37], Direct binding of neighboring hydrogen atoms in the adsorbed state to release hydrogen. The specific steps of HER under acidic conditions are as follows: H+ + e- + * → Hads (Volmer) (1) Hads + H+ + e- → H2 (Heyrovsky) (2) or 2Hads → H2 (Tafel) (3) where "*" denotes an active site on the catalyst surface, and "ads" indicates the adsorbed state of the intermediate (Hads). Under alkaline conditions, the steps of the HER are as follows: (4) H 2 O + e − → O H − + H a d s ( V o l m e r ) (5) H a d s + H 2 O + e − → O H − + H 2 ( H e y r o v s k y ) (6) o r 2 H a d s → H 2 ( T a f e l ) 1.1.1.2 Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) As another part of the water decomposition reaction, the oxygen-removal reaction (OER) is much more complex than the hydrogen-removal reaction (HER). The OER involves a multi-electron transfer process and typically consists of four steps [38]. However, the accumulation of energy barriers at each step makes OER kinetics extremely slow, ultimately leading to significant overpotentials that must be overcome during the reaction [39]. Therefore, it is crucial to design and develop catalysts capable of reducing the overpotential. The OER mechanism involves the adsorption and desorption of intermediates, namely OHads, Oads, OOHads, and O2ads (the adsorbate evolution mechanism, AEM) [40]. In both acidic and alkaline media, the Gibbs free energy required for the OER is 4.92 eV (note: the original 9.42 eV seems incorrect as it exceeds the theoretical maximum for a single-electron transfer reaction; and the Gibbs free energy required for the intermediate reactions is 3.21 eV [41]. If one step requires a higher Gibbs free energy, the other step will correspondingly require a lower amount, with the higher energy step being the rate-determining step and vice versa. Currently, there are two mainstream mechanisms for the OER process: (1) the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) where metals act as redox centers when the electronic states near the Fermi level exhibit metallic characteristics [42]; and (2) the lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) where oxygen serves as the redox center when the electronic states near the Fermi level exhibit oxygen-like behavior [43]. In the LOM pathway, the oxygen-oxygen bonding step is very facile, which is typically the rate-determining step in AEM. Therefore, LOM catalysts theoretically exhibit higher OER activity than AEM catalysts [44]. However, since the LOM pathway leads to the formation of oxygen vacancies, this accelerates the dissolution of metals, which in turn triggers the collapse of the catalyst structure and subsequent rapid deactivation. Therefore, catalysts following the LOM pathway tend to be relatively unstable. Under alkaline conditions, the steps of the OER are as follows: (7) O H − + * → O H a d s + e − (8) O H a d s + O H − → O a d s + H 2 O + e − (9) O a d s + O H − → O O H a d s + e − (10) O O H a d s + O H − → O 2 a d s + H 2 O + e − (11) O 2 a d s → O 2 + * (12) O v e r a l l : 4 O H − → 2 H 2 O + O 2 + 4 e − Under acidic conditions, the steps of the OER are as follows: (13) H 2 O + * → O H a d s + H + + e − (14) O H a d s → O a d s + H + + e − (15) O a d s + H 2 O → O O H a d s + H + + e − (16) O O H a d s → O 2 a d s + H + + e − (17) O 2 a d s → O 2 + * (18) O v e r a l l : 2 H 2 O → 4 H + + O 2 + 4 e − To date, although electrocatalytic materials with appropriate electronic structures have been developed to enhance the kinetics of slow electrocatalytic reactions and to reduce their overpotentials (even at higher current densities), the practical industrial applications of these electrocatalysts prepared by conventional methods are extremely limited and still present significant problems in production. The surface of the electrocatalyst has a crucial influence on the hydrogen and oxygen precipitation reactions, and the electrocatalytic performance can be enhanced by modifying the electronic structure, coordination environment and composition of the electrocatalyst surface. Hydrogen and oxygen precipitation reactions occur at the gas-liquid-solid three-phase interface, and therefore, the construction of reactant-friendly catalyst interfaces and the modulation of the mass transfer behavior of the gaseous products are also crucial for the water electrolysis process. 2 Superhydrophilic/Superaerophobic monometallic electrocatalyst 2.1 Ni-Based electrocatalyst The adhesion of hydrogen bubbles on the electrode surface adversely affects the electrolysis performance, and the release mechanism of hydrogen bubbles during electrocatalytic hydrogen and oxygen precipitation has not been fully investigated. Therefore, Kim and co-workers [45] systematically investigated the effect of nanoscale surface morphology on the release behavior of H2 bubbles and the performance of hydrogen precipitation reaction (HER). They employed a nickel-based catalyst consisting of nickel nanorods (Ni NRs) with controlled surface porosity and abundant earth reserves. The catalyst exhibited excellent superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic properties, and these properties varied with the surface porosity of the catalyst. The Ni catalyst with the highest porosity (≈52 %) is superhydrophobic to oxygen and exhibits the best HER performance of all the nickel-based catalysts. The combination of this property with the Ni catalyst porosity significantly enhances the electrocatalytic activity, including intrinsic activities such as specific activity and mass activity. It was shown that the supergas-phobicity of high porosity Ni, confirmed by NMR, can be combined with Pt and Cr with the best binding energy to further optimize the electrocatalytic performance. Meanwhile, Hao and his team [46] designed and synthesized a cost-effective and highly ductile catalyst on nickel-plated rice paper microspheres (Ni-RP).The shape and texture of the microspheres on the surface of the Ni-RP catalyst exhibited excellent super-gas-phobicity, which dramatically reduced the adherence of gas bubbles on the surface of the electrode. Among them, the nickel hydroxyl oxide (NiOxHy) and phosphorus doped nickel (PNi) catalysts on Ni-RP exhibited excellent catalytic performances for oxygen and hydrogen precipitation with overpotentials of 250 mV and 87 mV at current densities of 20 mA cm-2 (OER) and - 10 mA cm-2 (HER), respectively. Another, the hydrolysis cells using PNi/Ni-RP and NiOxHy/Ni-RP electrodes show excellent stability with an operating voltage of 1.55 V at a current density of 10 mA cm-2 and 100 h of stable operation in 1 M KOH. In order to further study the influence of the morphology of the catalyst surface on the efficiency of water electrolysis. Li and co-workers [47] proposed a simple two-step process involving hydrothermal assembly followed by consecutive thermal annealing in an H2/Ar atmosphere to rationally design super-hydrophilic Ni-based multicomponent nanorod-confined nanosheet arrays (Ni NCNAs) grown on nickel foam. This three-dimensional structure exposes more active sites, and the super-hydrophilicity ensures rapid wetting of the electrode surface by droplets. The close contact between nanorods and nanosheets [48,49] constructs highways for electron transfer, and the synergistic effect of Ni-related multicomponent modulated electronic structures [50,51] results in an operating potential of only −26 mV for HzOR and an overpotential of 47 mV for HER at a current density of 10 mA cm-2. Additionally, the Ni NCNAs electrode exhibits an ultra-low voltage of 23 mV at 10 mA cm-2 and an overpotential of 0.485 V at 892 mA cm-2, demonstrating exceptional bifunctional activity and accelerating hydrogen production efficiency. Meanwhile, Yu and co-workers [52] synthesized “super-phobic” Ni2P/NF nano-array structures on nickel foam (NF) substrates by a simple hydrothermal annealing strategy. The structure exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity, which could be attributed to its good electron transfer ability. Contact angle tests showed that bubbles on the surface of Ni2P/NF electrodes could be rapidly desorbed. In contrast, bare NF showed no significant change within 207.9 ms, and the bubbles adhered to the surface and were not released in time. Therefore, the super gas-phobicity of Ni₂P/NF electrocatalysts provides efficient catalytic activity and excellent stability at high current densities. In addition, some literatures reported that heterostructures based on self-supported nickel foam can also significantly enhance the catalytic performance. yang and co-workers [53] prepared a superhydrophilic self-supported Y-doped Ni2P electrode (Y-Ni2P@GP) by high temperature phosphide-electrodeposition. the overpotential was only 160 mV lower than that of Pt/C (20 %)@GP and pure Ni2P@GP electrode, and the stability was 300 h. The overpotential of this electrode is only 160 mV, which is lower than that of the Pt/C (20 %)@GP and pure Ni2P@GP electrodes, and the stability is up to 300 h. Y-Ni2P is hydrophilic with a contact angle of 16.51°, while Y-Ni2P-1@GP, Y-Ni2P-2@GP, and Pt/C (20 %)@GP electrodes are hydrophobic (the contact angles are 126.59°, 110.59°, and 126.59°, respectively). 126.59°, 110.25° and 139.68°, respectively). The contact angle test confirms the superhydrophilicity of the Y-Ni2P@GP electrode. The enhanced catalytic performance is attributed to the oxygenophilic Y atoms, which act as efficient hydrolysis sites to significantly accelerate the slow Volmer step in alkaline HERs, and the combination of Ni's efficient hydrogen-absorbing sites synergistically promotes the overall HER catalytic performance. He and his team [54] prepared a superhydrophilic self-supported microporous Ni(OH)ₓ/Ni3S2 heterostructured nickel foam electrocatalyst (Ni (OH)ₓ/Ni3S2/NF). The heterostructured electrode exhibits excellent stability with a droplet contact angle of 0° (full spreading) and overpotentials of 126, 193, and 238 mV at current densities of 100, 500, and 1000 mA cm-2, respectively, and current densities that are nearly unchanged after 1000 h of testing. The strong electronic coupling effect [55,56] at the heterostructure interface promotes the dissociation of H2O molecules and accelerates the HER kinetics in alkaline electrolytes. This study provides a new idea for the construction of superhydrophilic non-precious metal electrocatalysts for industrial hydrogen production. Recently, the use of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic logs as self-supported electrodes has been reported [57]. The material was prepared by depositing a Cu layer on the surface of untreated wood and then loading Ni-NiP catalysts, which retained the excellent intrinsic properties of wood while significantly enhancing the electrical conductivity. The tight coating of Cu and Ni-NiP catalysts on the surface of logs facilitated the charge transfer, while the superhydrophilicity and superhydrophobicity of the Ni-NiP/W electrode enhanced the mass transfer efficiency. The electrode exhibits excellent HER performance over a wide pH range and in seawater, surpassing many other wood-catalyzed electrodes. Especially in acidic and alkaline electrolytes, high current densities of 1000 mA cm-2 can be achieved with overpotentials below 300 mV. Remarkably, Ni-NiP/W has long-term stability at high current densities of 500 mA cm-2. Ni-NiP/W was found to be superhydrophilic, with microdroplets spreading rapidly on its surface in about 3 s (Fig. 3 a). In contrast, Ni-NiP/NF (Nickel Foam) and Ni-NiP/IF (Iron Foam) showed hydrophobicity with initial contact angles of 105.1° and 133.2° in air, respectively, which remained unchanged after 8 s. All studied electrodes showed superhydrophobicity with underwater bubble contact angles greater than 140° (Fig. 3b). This suggests that the log substrate is both superhydrophilic and superhydrophobic, whereas the pure nickel foam and pure iron foam only remain hydrophobic and hydrophobic. Interestingly, all electrodes inherited the surface properties of the substrates well and these properties were less affected by the Ni-NiP catalyst coating. Based on the above literature studies, the following conclusion can be drawn: high-performance nickel-based self-supported electrocatalysts can be synthesized by hydrothermal annealing and electrodeposition, and different morphologies such as nanosheets and nanorods can be formed on their surfaces. These morphologies are able to expose more active sites, promote the rapid desorption of gas bubbles from the surface of nickel-based catalysts, and exhibit lower overpotentials and long-term stability. Moerover, recent studies have reported excellent performance of electrocatalysts prepared by loading nickel on logs and depositing copper, a self-supporting structure that better promotes electron transfer while the contact angle is significantly reduced. The combination of the superhydrophilic and superhydrophobic nickel foam itself and the logs with good hydrophobicity gives the electrocatalysts outstanding superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic properties, thus enhancing the efficiency of water electrolysis. 2.2 Non-Ni-based electrocatalyst Although the catalytic performance of non-nickel-based materials is generally far inferior to that of nickel-based materials, their high-temperature and corrosion-resistant properties still make them uniquely valuable for electrocatalytic applications. Liu and his team [58] successfully prepared super-hydrophilic MoP quantum dots @ with a high specific surface area (SSA) of 976 m2·g-1 by using PMo12@UiO-66 as the precursor. porous carbon (MoP-QDs@PC) electrocatalysts. The optimized MoP-QDs@PC electrocatalysts exhibit excellent HER activity and durability under alkaline and acidic conditions with overpotentials below 197 mV and 233 mV, respectively. The contact angle experiments showed that the contact angle of MoC@PC material was 77.41°, while that of MoP-QDs@PC electrocatalyst was only 13.35°, confirming its superhydrophilicity, which was attributed to the abundant oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of MoP-QDs@PC as shown by XPS analysis. Under acidic/alkaline conditions, the charge transfer resistance (Rct) of MoP-QDs@PC was significantly lower than that of MoC@PC, MoP/ZrP₂O₇@C and other comparative materials, indicating that it possesses high efficiency and rapid charge transfer capability in HER process. Similarly, Chen and co-workers [59] prepared three-dimensional porous ordered nanoarray electrocatalysts CoₓP (denoted as NF@CoₓP, where 1 ≤ x ≤ 2) on nickel foam by γ-ray irradiation and annealing process without the use of reducing agents. By adjusting the temperature during the phosphatization process, they obtained superhydrophilic/ superhydrophobic 3D porous ordered nanoarray electrocatalysts. In situ technical tests showed that the superhydrophilicity of NF@CoₓP enhanced the ion transfer rate between CoₓP and the electrolyte, while the superhydrophobicity of the electrode promoted the rapid desorption of gas bubbles from the surface of NF@CoₓP. Besides, the overpotential of NF@CoₓP in 1 M KOH electrolyte was 272 mV at a current density of 200 mA cm-2, showing good HER catalytic performance. On this basis, MoS2/Mo2C materials were further investigated. Luo and co-workers [60] prepared MoS2/Mo2C electrocatalysts by a two-step method of hydrothermal synthesis and chemical vapor deposition. The catalysts exhibited overpotentials of 227 mV and 220 mV in acidic and alkaline media, respectively, at a high current density of 1000 mA cm-2. The formation of oxygen-containing groups on the surface of molybdenum carbide during hydrogen precipitation enhanced the mass transfer efficiency and accelerated the kinetics of the reaction, which provided new insights into the preparation of catalysts at high current densities. Contact angle experiments showed that the contact angle of MoS2/Mo2C was almost zero, indicating its excellent superhydrophilicity.The MoS2/Mo2C microspheres consisted of radially aligned MoS2 nanosheets with their edges modified by Mo2C nanoparticles. The prepared catalysts can expose more active sites, thus promoting rapid electron transfer and rapid desorption of hydrogen bubbles from the electrode surface. Experimental data show that the surface oxygen-modified Mo2C not only promotes the interfacial mass transfer of reactants and hydrogen bubbles on MoS2, but also accelerates the kinetics of water dissociation and hydrogen adsorption on the nickel foam, resulting in a good hydrogen precipitation reaction performance at high current density.
