The prepared electrocatalyst exhibited good dispersion and uniform three-dimensional conductivity. The CNF/cMWCNT/MoS2 catalysts exhibited superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic properties with a water contact angle of 0° and a gas bubble contact angle of 154.1° (as shown in Fig. 4 ). This structure accelerated the mass transfer process between gas and liquid. The CNF/cMWCNT/MoS2 showed excellent performance in hydrogen-excipitation reaction (HER), and this method provides a new way to design high-performance HER electrodes. 3 Superhydrophilic/Superaerophobic bimetallic electrocatalyst 3.1 NiFe electrocatalyst 3.1.1 Preparation of NiFe LDH electrocatalyst The performance of electrocatalysts is affected by many parameters, including the synthesis method. NiFe electrocatalysts are usually prepared by the following methods: electrodeposition and hydrothermal methods. Dai and co-workers [62] prepared NiFe layered double hydroxide (NiFe LDH) nanosheets on nickel foam (NF) in situ by hydrothermal method as an electrocatalyst for oxygen oxidization reaction (OER). Li and his team [63] used a simple impregnation method for the preparation of NiFe LDH. He and his team [64] prepared NiFe LDH by electrochemical etching process. The typical X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Fig. 5 a) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) images (Fig. 5b) of NiFe LDH showed that NiFe LDH could be successfully prepared by hydrothermal method [65]. Based on the bilayer layered structure of NiFe materials, which have higher surface energy and more active sites on the surface than monometallic nickel-based materials, Zhang and co-workers [66] successfully prepared SAL/SAB NiFe-LDHs electrodes by integrating super-atmophilic (SAL) stripes with super-absorbent (SAB) NiFe-LDHs onto nickel plates. The electrode significantly enhanced the mass transfer capability, including the rapid transport and effective desorption of gas bubbles. Among them, the SAL stripes consisting of a large number of hydrophobic SiO2 nanoparticles exhibited super-gasophilicity with a bubble contact angle of 0° (as shown in Fig. 6 a). In order to enhance the cohesion between the hydrophobic nanoparticles and the substrate, the authors chose a thin layer of polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) as a binder to firmly bond the nanoparticles to the substrate. In the bubble adhesion test, it was difficult to accurately measure the adhesion force due to the ease of adsorption and spreading of the bubbles on the SAL stripes, but this phenomenon suggests that the adhesion of the bubbles to the SAL stripes is quite high. Specifically, the electrode structure consists of SAL stripes with a width of 500 μm and SAB catalyst stripes with a width of 250 μm, which are arranged in a horizontal alternating pattern. As shown in Fig. 6b, the gaps between the SAL stripes were filled with NiFe-LDHs catalysts, which have high intrinsic surface energy and highly wrinkled nanostructures, making their surfaces easy to be wetted by water and exhibiting excellent superhydrophilicity. The underwater bubble contact angle test showed that a water layer could be formed on the surface of NiFe-LDHs electrodes, which further prevented the direct contact between the solution and the electrode surface. As shown in Fig. 6c, the bubble contact angle is 156.3°, showing excellent superhydrophobicity, and the adhesion of bubbles to NiFe-LDHs electrodes is almost zero. NiFe-LDHs electrodes drive H2 and O₂ bubbles away from the reaction system by asymmetric Laplace pressure[67] and accelerate the diffusion of dissolved gases by shortening their diffusion distance. This SAL/SAB NiFe-LDHs electrode exhibits excellent hydrogenation reaction (HER) activity, with overpotentials of −76 mV at a current density of −10 mA cm-2 and 253 mV at 100 mA cm-2. This bifunctional electrode further enhances the overall water decomposition performance. Additionally, Shen and co-workers [68] rapidly synthesized nickel-iron hydroxyl oxide nanosheets (FF-FN) on iron foams (FF) by a single-pot solid-phase method at room temperature. The method is simple and does not require complex steps, in which FF serves as a conductive carrier and iron source for the in situ synthesis of nickel-iron based oxygen precipitation reaction (OER) active materials. The prepared FF-FN exhibits a nanoflower-like array morphology consisting of nanosheets. The resulting hierarchical 3D nanostructures exhibited superhydrophilicity to facilitate electrolyte diffusion, and the rapid desorption of bubbles demonstrated their underwater superhydrophobicity. They measured the bubble contact angles (CAs) as shown in Fig. 7 a-c. The contact angles of the comparison samples FF, RuO2/FF and FF-FN were 127°, 118° and 0°, respectively, which indicated that the hierarchical nanostructures on the electrode surface improved the surface wettability and further demonstrated the superhydrophilicity of the FF-FN electrode. They also investigated the oxygen-phobicity of the prepared electrodes by underwater bubble contact angle measurements. The surface wettability of the prepared electrocatalysts is depicted in Fig. 7d-f. The bubble contact angles of FF, RuO₂/FF and FF-FN were 125°, 135° and 150°, respectively, indicating that the nanoflowering FF-FN possessed stronger oxygen-hydrophobicity than that of pure FF and commercial RuO2/FF. Fig. 7 g-l further illustrates the superior superhydrophilicity and superhydrophobicity of FF-FN. They also studied the oxygen precipitation behavior of the samples using a high-speed digital camera and analyzed the bubble size distribution. As shown in Fig. 7m-q, the nanoflowering FF-FN electrodes had the smallest average bubble diameter (0.16 mm) compared to the average bubble diameter of pure FF (0.26 mm) and commercial RuO2/FF (0.23 mm), which suggests that FF-FN has the lowest bubble resistance, and that generated bubbles can be separated from the surface of the prepared electrodes efficiently and quickly. This phenomenon was caused by the discontinuous state of the three-phase contact line (TPCL) [69], which weakened the adhesion force on the electrode surface and inhibited the massive aggregation of bubbles. The study showed that the super-hydrophilicity had a strong ability to approach the electrolyte solution, maximizing active sites. The prepared FF-FN exhibited an ultra-low overpotential of 195 mV and a small Tafel slope of 34 mV dec‑1 at 10 mA cm-2. Further theoretical studies have shown that during the electrochemical self-construction of NiFe-based hydroxides, the lattice oxygen involved in the reaction can significantly reduce the overpotential of the OER through the dominant lattice oxygen mechanism. Rechargeable zinc-air batteries [70] assembled with the prepared FF-FN directly as the cathode exhibited good cycling performance. This work provides a powerful electrocatalyst for converting commercial iron foams into sustainable energy conversion and storage systems. Besides, some researchers have investigated three-dimensional NiFe electrodes with abundant gas channels. Dong and co-workers [71] constructed a three-dimensional NiFe electrode with a superhydrophilic/supergas-phobic surface and abundant gas channels by an in situ bubble template method. Instead of focusing on the surface of the electrode, the team shifted the focus to the internal gas channels, which act as gas transport conduits during the OER and HER, allowing for the rapid release of gas bubbles generated through the channels. The average diameter of these gas channels is <30 μm, which accelerates electrolyte penetration through capillary pressure. The contact angle test showed that when the droplet was placed on the surface of nickel foam (NF), there was no obvious water wetting phenomenon and no significant change within 7 s; while on Ni0.75Fe0.25/NF surface, the droplet was completely wetted within 20 ms, showing the good superhydrophilicity of this electrode. The underwater bubble contact angle test showed that the bare NF sample had a contact angle of 114°, while Ni0.75Fe0.25/NF samples was 150°, confirming its excellent super-airtightness underwater. Adhesion tests and the contact behavior of the bubbles with the electrode surface further illustrate the excellent superhydrophobicity of Ni0.75Fe0.25/NF electrode surfaces are superhydrophilic/ superhydrophobic. The average diameter of the released bubbles was observed to be 30 μm at a current density of 100 mA cm-2. The optimized Ni0.75Fe0.25/NF electrodes exhibited good catalytic activity for both HER and OER at current densities up to 500 mA cm-2, with overpotentials of 214 mV and 327 mV, respectively, which effectively facilitated the catalytic processes of OER and HER, and significantly enhanced the overall water decomposition efficiency. Based on the above literature, it can be concluded that nickel-iron layered double hydroxides (NiFe-LDHs), due to their excellent intrinsic surface energy and highly undulating nanostructures, can form a liquid film on their surfaces in bubble contact angle experiments, which reduces the contact area of the electrode surface with the solution. It is shown that the three-dimensional nanostructures NiFe-LDHs synthesized on FF or NF make their internal gas-poor channels more favorable for electrolyte diffusion through capillary pressure effect. This further indicates that nickel-iron layered double hydroxides have excellent super-hydrophilicity and super-aerophobicity, significantly reducing the overpotential of the electrocatalyst, thus improving the efficiency of water splitting. 3.1.2 Heterostructure Numerous studies have shown that interfacial engineering is crucial for enhancing the performance of heterostructured electrocatalysts. Heterostructured electrocatalysts with abundant interfaces can significantly accelerate the kinetics of hydrogen precipitation catalysis under alkaline conditions, which can be attributed to their ability to balance the adsorption/desorption behaviors of intermediates at the interface [72–74]. In addition, interfacial engineering can effectively modulate the electronic structure of the active site through electronic interactions, interfacial bonding, and lattice strains to optimize the binding energy of target intermediates (e.g., hydrogen intermediates) in an appropriate manner. Firstly, some researchers have carried out studies on nickel foam-loaded nickel sulfide-nickel-iron electrocatalytic materials.Wu and co-workers [75] prepared Ni3S2 NiFe-LDHs/NFs as an oxygen-removal reaction (OER) electrocatalyst by a one-pot solution process. Among them, Ni3S2 was used as a mediator to realize the in situ growth of NiFe-LDH heterostructured porous nanosheets on nickel foam (NF) within 15 min at room temperature. The porous nanosheet-structured Ni3S2 NiFe-LDH heterogeneous interface can expose more active sites [76,77], reduce the adhesion of the generated bubbles on the surface of the electrocatalysts, and accelerate the rapid release of bubbles, which significantly improves the mass-transfer efficiency and facilitates the proton transfer kinetics. When the droplets were placed on the surface of the Ni3S2 NiFe-LDHs/NF catalysts, the droplets were fully infiltrated and the contact angle was close to zero, indicating excellent superhydrophilicity. The researchers recorded the bubble release behavior by digital microscopy at a current density of 25 mA cm-2, and found that the bubbles on the bare NF surface were tightly adhered, with a maximum size of 400 μm; the bubbles generated on the NiFe-LDHs/NF surface were generally smaller than 100 μm; and the smallest bubbles were formed on the Ni3S2 NiFe-LDHs/NF-2 surface (all <30 μm), and it is very easy to quickly desorb from the electrode surface. This demonstrates that the active sites of Ni3S2 NiFe-LDHs/NF-2 can be more fully exposed to the surrounding electrolyte, which exhibits excellent supergas-phobicity. The electrode exhibits excellent durability of 240 h in 1.0 M KOH solution and requires only 240 mV overpotential at a current density of 100 mA cm-2, indicating that the prepared Ni3S2 NiFe-LDHs/NF-2 electrodes significantly enhance the overall water decomposition performance. Heterostructures constructed by introducing cobalt elements were further investigated in depth based on the previous work of some researchers. Liu and co-workers [78] synthesized NiFe-LDH-coated Co9S8 Ni3S2 heterostructures on nickel foam (NF) by hydrothermal method (NiFe-LDH@Co9S8 Ni3S2/NF). The unique hierarchical structure of this heterostructure exposes more active sites, while the synergistic effect and strong electronic interactions between Co9S8 Ni3S2 and NiFe-LDH enhance the oxygen-elimination reaction (OER) activity [79]. NiFe-LDH@Co9S8 Ni3S2/NF exhibits hydrophilicity, which promotes sufficient contact between the electrocatalyst and the electrolyte. Its overpotential was 274 mV at 1000 mA cm-2 current density and 298 mV in alkaline seawater, and it could be operated stably at 500 mA cm-2 current density for 200 h in both solutions, showing excellent stability. Furthermore, some researchers have investigated carbon cloth-loaded electrocatalytic materials, and Wang and co-workers successfully synthesized a highly efficient heterostructure, a composite catalyst consisting of cauliflower-like NiFe alloy anchored on nickel hydroxide carbonate (NiFeCH) flakes and loaded on the surface of a carbon cloth (CC) (NiFe/NiFeCH/CC). This trifunctional electrocatalyst enables large hydrogen production through rapid decomposition of water and urea [80]. By tuning and optimizing the Ni/Fe ratio, thethe NiFe/NiFeCH/CC heterostructure exhibited excellent performance in the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) due to the special morphology and synergistic effect between the Ni/Fe ratio and NiFeCH. The authors measured the surface wettability of the prepared electrodes in the electrolyte using bubble contact angle measurements.the initial bubble contact angle of NiFe/NiFeCH/CC was 150.5°, Furthermore, the bubble contact angle is slightly increased, which enhances the ability of bubbles to detach from the surface of the NiFe/NiFeCH/CC electrode, while the electrode still exhibits excellent superhydrophilicity. This property also provides NiFe/NiFeCH/CC electrodes with longer term stability and durability. The increased contact angle of the bubbles facilitates the overall hydrolysis reaction. Based on previous studies, researchers have vulcanized carbon cloth-loaded NiFe-based materials and explored the properties of the resulting heterostructures. The new heterostructures formed by further phosphatization on the NiFe/NiFeCH/CC heterostructures showed even better performance. Li and his team [81] designed a crystalline nickel-iron phosphide (NiFeP) amorphous phosphorus-doped hydroxyl iron oxide (P-FeOOH) heterostructure (P-NiFeOₓHy) as efficient multifunctional water electrolysis electrocatalysts. Among them, the NiFeP nanocrystals have abundant active sites and remarkable electronic conductivity, while the amorphous P-FeOOH optimizes the adsorption energy for oxygen-containing species. As shown in Fig. 8 , the crystalline/ amorphous P-NiFeOₓHy heterostructure is further enhanced by the synergistic effect of hydrophilic and superhydrophobic surfaces to enrich the active sites with efficient charge/mass transfer capability. The researchers tested P-NiFeOₓHy for underwater bubble contact angle and static droplet contact angle, and its superhydrophilic surface is attributed to the hydroxyl group (OH) in FeOOH and phosphorus (P) in NiFeP, both of which are prone to adsorption of hydrogen protons from water molecules. In addition, P-NiFeOₓHy exhibits extremely low overpotentials at a current density of 10 mA cm-2: the oxygen-removal reaction (OER) is 159.2 mV, and the hydrogen-removal reaction (HER) is 20.8 mV. In summary, the synergistic effect of superhydrophobicity and superhydrophilicity can make full use of the active sites to significantly improve the overall water decomposition efficiency. decomposition efficiency. From the above literature, it can be summarized that the heterojunction structure is capable of electronic intermodulation and specific synergistic effects between charges. Heterojunctions formed by sulfides, phosphides and nickel-iron layered double hydroxides (NiFe-LDHs) expose more active sites on the electrocatalytic surfaces, significantly lowering the overpotentials, and at the same time exhibit excellent superhydrophilicity and superhydrophobicity with outstanding stability. 3.1.3 Heteroatom doping Heteroatom doping [82,83] is an effective design strategy by introducing dopants into the lattice structure of the host to form efficient and stable catalytically active sites. This strategy can optimize a variety of properties such as the electronic structure, vacancy concentration, phase composition and wettability of the material, and more importantly, it can modulate the electronic state of the material [84] to improve its interaction with the oxygen intermediates in terms of electrical conductivity, electronic energy bands or charge distribution [85]. Doping is mainly categorized into metal ion doping and non-metal ion doping [86], where metal ions are usually particles with a radius similar to that of the host metal, while non-metal ions mainly include elements such as N, P, S, and B [87]. Heteroatom doping can effectively modify the electrocatalyst surface and accelerate the rapid desorption of bubbles from the electrode surface. In order to regulate the bubble behavior on gas-producing electrodes, researchers have proposed interfacial engineering strategies such as the construction of micro/nanostructures and the modification of special wettability [88,89]. Lei and co-workers [90] reported platinum quantum dot-modified sulfur-doped nickel-iron layered double hydroxides (Pt@S-NiFe LDHs), which exhibited excellent catalytic performance for hydrogenation reaction (HER) for industrial applications, attributed to the strong binding energy and fast bubble release efficiency of the Pt@S-NiFe LDHs. This is attributed to the strong binding energy and fast bubble release efficiency of Pt@S-NiFe LDHs. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the 40 % platinum/carbon (Pt/C) electrodes showed few bubbles on the surface at current densities of 10 or 20 mA cm-2, while a large number of bubbles accumulated on the surface when the current density was increased to 50 or 100 mA cm-2; in contrast, the Pt@S-NiFe LDH electrodes showed no significant bubble aggregation at either low or high current conditions. As shown in Fig. 9b, the contact angle between the bare nickel foam and the underwater bubbles is 133°, while the contact angle between Pt@S-NiFe LDH and the bubbles is about 164°, indicating that Pt@S-NiFe LDH is hydrophobic to the bubbles (Note: the contact angle of 164° actually characterizes a strong hydrophobicity rather than a hydrophilicity), which effectively improves the catalytic performance of Pt@S-NiFe LDH in both the hydrogen excipitating reaction (HER) and the oxygen excipitating reaction (OER). Based on the idea of sulfur-doped nickel-iron layered double hydroxides, Jiang and co-workers [91] prepared sulfur-doped nickel-iron hydroxyl oxide (S-Ni(Fe)OOH) ultrathin nanosheets in situ by a one-step method at room temperature. Theoretical calculations showed that the introduction of S modulated the chemisorption behavior of the material towards oxygen-containing intermediates [92], facilitated the conversion of *OH to *O, and thus enhanced the intrinsic oxygen-evacuation reaction (OER) activity of S-Ni (Fe) OOH. The contact angles of Ni(Fe)OOH and S-Ni(Fe)OOH were 68° (wetting time 211 ms) and 0° (wetting time 20 ms), respectively. The superhydrophilicity of the electrodes was confirmed. The prepared S-Ni(Fe)OOH showed excellent OER stability and activity in 5 M KOH, alkaline wastewater and seawater, and only 198 mV, 275 mV and 284 mV overpotentials were required to reach 500 mA cm-2 current density. This study provides a simple method for the preparation of efficient alkaline wastewater and seawater oxidation catalysts [93]. Sulfur doping effectively enhanced the performance of NiFe-based materials, so researchers further carried out selenium doping related studies. Huang and co-workers [94] developed an etch-assisted synthesis method to integrate highly active NiFe2O4 nanoparticles with stabilized and activated NiOOH skeletons directly onto commercial stainless steel surfaces. The NiFe2O4-xSeₓ/NiOOH electrodes obtained after selenization treatment exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity. NiFe2O4/NiOOH and NiFe2O4-xSeₓ/ NiOOH both exhibited excellent superhydrophilicity, suggesting that the selenation treatment provided a more hydrophilic surface, which is conducive to the accelerated mass transfer and highlighted the importance of the three-dimensional heterostructures in the improvement of surface wettability [95]. More importantly, the catalyst maintained its durability for hundreds of hours at a stable current output of 100 mA cm-2. The prepared selenium-doped samples NiFe2O4-xSeₓ/NiOOH enhanced the electrocatalytic performance of both the oxygen removal reactions (OER) and the hydrogen-removal reaction (HER), thus effectively contributing to the overall hydropyrolysis efficiency. Both sulfur doping and selenium doping effectively enhanced the performance of nickel-iron based electrocatalytic materials, which enhanced the intrinsic oxygenation reaction (OER) activity of the catalysts by modulating the chemisorption of oxygen-containing intermediates and facilitating the *OH to *O conversion. Meanwhile, the doping brought the droplets into full contact with the electrolyte, which exhibited excellent hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity and significantly reduced the overpotential, confirming that the doping strategy is an effective means to enhance the electrocatalytic performance. 3.1.4 Oxygen vacancy The concept of oxygen vacancies was first introduced in the 1960s to study the interaction mechanism between gases and solid metal oxides. under specific external conditions such as high temperatures, oxygen atoms in the lattice may detach, leading to oxygen deficiency and the formation of oxygen vacancies. Oxygen vacancies can modulate the electronic structure of metal oxides and optimize the adsorption energy of reactants on the catalyst surface, thus lowering the reaction energy barrier and promoting molecular activation. In catalysts, oxygen vacancies (OVs) have a synergistic effect with neighboring active metal sites. Li and co-workers [96] successfully synthesized NiFe-LDH (NiFe/IF) loaded on iron foams (IFs) by a one-step hydrothermal etching method, which is enriched with oxygen vacancies and possesses an excellent super-hydrophilic/super-gas-phobic surface, and thus exhibits excellent electrocatalytic properties. At current densities of 10 and 1000 mA cm-2, its overpotentials are 203.2 and 480.2 mV, respectively. Moreover, it can operate stably for 40 h at a current density of 500 mA cm-2. Notably, under industrial conditions (6 M KOH and 85 °C), it also demonstrates lasting stability at current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm-2. NiFe LDH can undergo surface reconstruction to form NiOOH in an electrooxidative environment [97]. Furthermore, a potential of only 1.57 V is required to provide a current density of 10 mA cm-2 when NiFe/IF is used as the anode and cathode for the total water decomposition process. The XPS spectra of its O1s can be categorized into three states: O1 (532.8 eV), O2 (531.2 eV), and O3, which represent adsorbed oxygen [98], oxygen vacancies [99], and metal-oxygen bonding [100], respectively.The oxygen content of NiFe/IF is 57.74 %, which is much higher than that of Fe/IF (35.7 %), indicating that NiFe-LDH contains more oxygen vacancies. The oxygen vacancies are beneficial to enhance the intrinsic activity of the active sites and improve the electrical conductivity, which in turn enhance the electrocatalytic activity. On this basis, researchers have investigated the phosphatization of nickel-iron based materials. Wang and co-workers [101] prepared dense superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic nickel-iron phosphide nano-arrays (NiFe-Vo-P). As shown in Fig. 10 , the electrocatalyst has a high intrinsic activity due to the enrichment of oxygen vacancies and achieves an overpotential of 179 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm-2. This is attributed to the residual phosphate anions in NiFeOOH formed in situ during oxygen precipitation, which effectively weakened the adsorption strength of oxygenated intermediates. The prepared superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic electrocatalyst nano-arrays can expose more active sites and promote proton transfer. Moreover, when NiFe-Vo-P was used as both anode and cathode of the fully dissociated water, a cell voltage of only 1.44 V was required at a current density of 10 mA cm-2, and the overpotential at a current density of 400 mA cm-2 was 1.92 V. These results indicate that the electrocatalyst exhibits excellent electrocatalytic performances of oxygen- and hydrogen-removing (OER) electrocatalytic properties, which provides a useful idea for the development of bifunctional electrocatalysts. The results show that the electrocatalyst exhibits excellent OER and HER electrocatalytic performance, which provides useful ideas for the development of bifunctional electrocatalysts. Some researchers have investigated the oxygen vacancies formed by the introduction of cobalt into the nickel-iron system, and the results show that it also exhibits excellent performance. Li and co-workers [101] synthesized NiFe-LDH nanoflowers and co-doped NiFe-LDH nanopins on graphite felts (TGFs) by an in situ self-assembly strategy. It was found that Co doping in NiFe-LDH nano-arrays could significantly enhance the specific surface area and oxygen vacancy density [102,103]. Graphite mats act as a conductive backbone to prevent active site detachment, and the oxygen vacancies in Co3 Ni₇Fe₃ LDH/TGF promote efficient electrolyte diffusion through modulation of the electronic configuration in combination with superhydrophilicity, a synergistic effect that imparts excellent oxygen-energy reactivity (OER) performance: overpotentials of only 252 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm-2, Tafel slope 63.13 mV dec‑1, and stability at high current densities. This study provides new perspectives for the application of carbon substrate non-precious metal catalysts for hydrogen production. Additionally, The researchers tested the wettability of the materials.The contact angle of Co3 Ni7Fe3 LDH/TGF was 0°, whereas that of the pure graphite felt (TGF) was 144.9°, suggesting that the Co3 Ni7Fe3 LDH/TGF has an excellent superhydrophilicity. This is attributed to the presence of OH- and CO3 2- groups in Co3 Ni7Fe3 LDH/TGF and the increase in the concentration of oxygen vacancies OH- and CO3 2- groups promote the formation of hydrogen bonds with hydrogen protons in water molecules, while oxygen vacancies enhance the adsorption of H2O molecules on the catalyst surface. This property promotes electrolyte permeation, hydroxyl migration and oxygen release.The excellent electrolyte wettability of Co3 Ni7Fe3 LDH/TGF exposes abundant active sites on the catalyst surface and accelerates proton transfer, which effectively enhances the electrocatalytic performance. It has been shown that the introduction of elements such as phosphorus and cobalt can generate a large number of oxygen vacancies and significantly enhance the electrochemical performance. Based on this, Du and co-workers [104] reported the in situ growth of CeₓCo3-ₓO4 nanoneedle/microflower arrays on the surface of nickel foams, which resulted in electrocatalysts with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic properties. The hierarchical structure and super amphiphilic interface of Co3O4 can be optimized by controlling the doping of Ce elements. Thanks to the synergistic effect of oxygen vacancies and Ce elements, the catalysts exhibited excellent OER performance with an overpotential of 282 mV and a Tafel slope of 81.4 mV dec‑1 at 20 mA cm-2 current density. At an overpotential of 350 mV, Ce0.12Co2.88O4 has a turnover frequency (TOF) of 0.0279 s-1, which is 9.3 times higher than that of pure Co3O4. Its superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic property accelerates the release of bubble products from the electrode surface, further enhancing the OER catalytic efficiency. Despite the variety of methods for generating oxygen vacancies, how to synergistically enhance the OER performance by controllable and uniform oxygen vacancy modulation remains a major challenge. Oxygen vacancies can alter the electronic configuration. They can enhance the adsorption of water molecules on the surface of the electrocatalyst, thereby promoting the penetration of the electrolyte, the migration of hydroxide ions, and the release of oxygen. There are a large number of active sites on the surface of the catalyst, which shows a lower Tafel slope and more long-lasting stability. 3.2 Non-NiFe electrocatalysts Compared with Ni-Fe-based materials, non-Ni-Fe-based materials are still widely used in the field of electrocatalysis, although their contents are extremely low and their catalytic performance, durability and stability are far inferior to those of the former. As well, Zhang and co-workers [105] reported a method to prepare ultrathin two-dimensional Ni-Mo alloy nanosheets by in situ topological reduction. The bubble adhesion test on Ni-Mo alloys on different electrodes showed that the bubble adhesion was the smallest; the bubble release behavior under optical microscope showed that the bubble release rate on the surface of Ni-Mo alloys was the fastest, which confirmed the excellent performance of this electrocatalytic material. Based on the above researchers' studies on NiMoN catalytic materials, other researchers have further investigated the nitridation and sulfidation of NiMoN materials. Fan and co-workers [106] prepared three-dimensional hollow Ni/NiMoN hierarchical structures by a one-pot hydrothermal method, which showed excellent superhydrophilicity and superhydrophobicity with contact angles of 6.07° and 155.7° for bubbles, respectively. The complex nanosheet arrays of Ni/NiMoN electrodes [107,108] facilitated the rapid desorption of gas bubbles from the electrode surface. Zhang and co-workers [109] successfully synthesized amorphous Ni3S2/NiMoS electrocatalysts on nickel foams by a simple hydrothermal method, which had a unique “sugar-coated” nanoscale structure, and its heterogeneous structure facilitated the rapid desorption of gas bubbles from the electrode surface. The heterogeneous structure of the catalyst favors the hydrogenation reaction (HER) under alkaline conditions and exposes a large number of active sites. Contact angle experiments showed that the contact angle of Ni3S2/NiMoS/NF was 0°, confirming the excellent superhydrophilicity of this electrocatalyst. Furthermore, researchers have also investigated cobalt-nickel-based materials. Jin and co-workers [110] synthesized graded bimetallic phosphides (CoP@Ni2P) on nickel foam by a simple method. The graded heterostructured electrode exhibited excellent electrocatalytic performance due to the synergistic effect of superhydrophobicity, fast electron transfer capability and active site exposure on the electrode surface. Its work provides an advanced transition metal-based phosphide for large-scale hydrogen production. The experimental results show that the layered structure of the supergas-phobic CoP@Ni₂P promotes the rapid release of H2 bubbles, which enhances the activity and stability of the hydrogen extraction reaction (HER) at high current densities. Based on the excellent hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity exhibited by nickel-cobalt phosphides, researchers have further carried out nitridation studies on nickel-cobalt-based materials. Lv and co-workers [111] successfully synthesized three-dimensional (3D) floral bimetallic nitrides (Co2NiN) on flexible carbon cloth (CC) by hydrothermal method. The synergistic effect of Ni3N, CoN and metal Co effectively enhances the electron transfer rate and exposes more active sites on the electrode surface, and the Co2NiN/CC electrode exhibits excellent electrocatalytic performance for both hydrogen-energy-removal (HER) and oxygen-energy-removal (OER) reactions in alkaline medium, with only 1457 V required for the total water decomposition process at a current density of 10 mA cm-2. This study provides an effective way for the preparation of bimetallic nitride electrocatalysts [112–114]. Meanwhile, Dong and co-workers [115] synthesized Co-Ni₃N/NF heterostructured electrocatalysts by a simple hydrothermal method. Cobalt doping and structural defects synergistically regulated the electronic configuration and intrinsic activity of the heterostructured electrodes, which demonstrated that the electrodes possessed the characteristics of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic. Furthermore, Yang and co-workers [116] reported a general method for the electrosynthesis of metal hydroxides/oxides on various substrates by reducing acidic anions. On graphite plates, the insertion of nitrate ions into the graphene interlayers significantly enhances the electrodeposition support interface, realizing high-quality loading and endowing the materials with superhydrophilic/hydrophobic properties. In situ Raman spectroscopy and in situ X-ray diffraction indicate that cerium doping promotes the formation of electrocatalytically active γ-phase nickel oxides on the exposed (003) crystal surface. Thus, combining anionic intercalation with cathodic electrodeposition provides a promising direction for the construction of high-performance electrochemical electrodes. 4 Superhydrophilic/Superaerophobic multi-metal electrocatalyst While previous studies have focused extensively and in-depth on two-dimensional electrode materials, this paper reports a class of trimetallic elemental electrocatalysts with three-dimensional network structures, which exhibit excellent catalytic performance for both hydrogen-extraction reaction (HER) and oxygen-extraction reaction (OER). For example, inspired by the excellent electrocatalytic performance of three-dimensional (3D) networked polyethyleneimine (PEI) hydrogel-coated bare nickel foam (NF) in HER, the researchers have developed a novel electrode system with high activity and stability through composite metal doping and network structure design. Ma and co-workers [117] successfully synthesized a trimetallic (Fe, Co, Ni) spinel/carbon/NF (FeCoNiOx/C/NF) electrocatalyst with a 3D network structure using an impregnation-foam calcination strategy at low temperatures. This three-dimensional network structure provides the material with high specific surface area and interconnected fast electron transport channels. The wettability test showed that the contact angle between the bare NF and the liquid droplets was 110°, indicating that the surface of the electrode was poorly wetted, while the liquid droplets could completely wet the surface of the FeCoNiOx/C/NF electrode with a contact angle of 0°, confirming that the electrocatalyst has excellent superhydrophilicity. In addition, the underwater bubble contact angle of bare NF was 133°, while that of FeCoNiOx/C/NF was 152°, indicating that the latter has excellent superhydrophobicity. In recent years, NiFe bimetallic electrocatalysts have been widely studied and have shown optimal performance in many bimetallic systems. Ma and co-workers [118] reported an open three-dimensional electrode composed of iron (Fe)-cobalt (Co)-nickel (Ni) (oxy)hydroxide nanorods (NRs) grown in situ on high-aspect-ratio nickel micropillar arrays (NCA), which was beneficial for electrocatalytic water splitting. Compared with flat nickel foam, the NCA catalyst improved both the loaded surface area and electrode wettability. As shown in Fig. 11 , the contact angles between the electrode surface and droplets were 0° and 163°, respectively, indicating the prepared electrocatalyst's superhydrophilicity and superaerophobicity. Based on the research on iron-cobalt-nickel electrode materials, some researchers have conducted studies on iron-cobalt and nickel-cobalt electrode materials. He and co-workers [119] utilized a surface engineering strategy to in situ prepare cobalt-Prussian blue analogs on NiCo layered double hydroxides to obtain a three-dimensional hierarchical heterogeneous structure precursor (NiCo-CoFe-PBA). After phosphating, this precursor could be further converted into a trimetallic phosphide (NiCoP/CoFeP@NF), which directly served as an efficient self-supporting electrode for water and urea electrolysis. achieving battery voltages of 1.61 V and 1.46 V at a current density of 10 mA cm-2 with overpotentials. The contact angle experiments and underwater bubble contact angle experiments show that the droplets on the electrode surface can be completely spread within 10 ms with a contact angle of 0°, indicating that the electrode is superhydrophilic; in comparison, the contact angle (CA) of pristine nickel foam (NF) is 114.8° In addition, the underwater bubble contact angles of 125.5°, 141.4°, 143.5°, 154.2°, and 155.3° for NF, NiCo-LDH@NF, NiCoP@NF, NiCo-CoFe-PBA-12, and NiCoP/CoFeP@NF-12, respectively, showed excellent hydrophobicity.In addition, some researchers have conducted a study on the PdFeCo electrode material. Niyitanga and co-workers [120] prepared a cobalt oxide trimetallic PdFeCo3-xO4 composite on NF using an impregnation-hydrothermal calcination strategy, denoted as PdFeCo3-xO4/NF. The synergistic effect between PdFe bimetals exposed more active sites in Co3-xO4/NF. The PdFeCo3-xO4/NF could operate stably for over 50 h at a current density of 500 mA cm-2, indicating its electrocatalyst's enduring tolerance. This three-dimensional porous structure [121,122] could accelerate the deposition efficiency of the catalyst and provide a larger specific surface area, Additionally, wettability tests revealed that PdFeCo3-xO4/NF exhibited excellent superhydrophilic/superaerophobic properties. Furthermore, Jeong and co-workers [123] successfully synthesized a zero-dimensional (0D)-one-dimensional (1D) PrBa0.5Sr0.5Co1.5Fe0.5O5+δ (PBSCF)-Ni3S2 heterogeneous structure self-supporting catalytic electrode through interface and morphology engineering. The wettability test shows that the bubble size on the bare NF surface is large, the bubble size on the Ni3S2 electrode surface is significantly smaller than that on the NF surface, while the bubble size of PBSCF-Ni3S2 is greatly reduced. It is not easy to accumulate a large amount on the electrode surface, thus increasing the contact area between the electrolyte and the electrode, indicating that it has excellent superhydrophobicity. The theoretical breakdown voltage of urea electrolysis is relatively low, typically around 0.37 V, compared to the conventional hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution reactions (hydrogen production by water splitting). Due to the lower theoretical decomposition voltage of urea electrolysis, the actual power consumption is usually lower than that of water electrolysis for the same amount of hydrogen production. Therefore, the energy consumption of the whole hydrogen production process is reduced to a certain extent, and the energy utilization efficiency is improved. Urea electrolysis [124–126] represents a highly environmentally friendly and energy-efficient process for hydrogen production, yet the lack of efficient and sustainable amperometric current density electrocatalysts poses a major challenge to its commercialization. Andaveh and co-workers [127] prepared CoMn/CuNiP/NF with superhydrophilic/superaerophobic properties, which exhibited excellent catalytic performance during the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) with overpotentials of 33.8, 184.4, and 234.8 mV at current densities of 10, 500, and 1000 mA cm-2 respectively, and during the urea oxidation reaction (UOR) [128–130] with overpotentials of 1.28, 1.43, and 1.51 V (vs RHE) at the same current densities. For the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), Overpotentials of 1.45, 1.67, and 1.74 V (relative to RHE) were obtained at 10, 500, and 1000 mA cm-2, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results indicate that the CoMn/CuNiP electrode surface is rich in redox couples such as Ni2+/Ni2+, Cu+/Cu2+, Co2+/Co2+, and Mn2+/Mn2+, which are essential for the formation of NiOOH, MnOOH, and CoOOH active sites for OER and UOR, thereby enhancing the MnOOH and CoOOH, which are essential for the formation of the active sites of OER and UOR, thus increasing the electrocatalytic activity. This electrode maintains a high Faraday efficiency for 500 h. As well to hydrogen, urea electrolysis produces products such as nitrogen and carbon dioxide. These products can be further used in other industrial processes. For example, carbon dioxide can be used to synthesize chemical products and nitrogen can be used as a chemical raw material or protective gas. This improves the economic efficiency and resource utilization of the entire reaction process. Moreover, urea electrolysis has relatively weak corrosion on electrode materials, which is conducive to prolonging the service life of electrodes. Furthermore, cobalt-molybdenum-iron phosphide electrode materials have also been studied. Feng and co-workers [131] recently reported a bifunctional CoMoP-FexP/NF catalyst that also exhibited superhydrophilic properties, enabling more active sites to be exposed on its surface and effectively enhancing the contact between the electrolyte and the electrode. Additionally, Mu and co-workers [132] prepared a W-doped sulfide heterogeneous structure (W-MoS2/FeNi2S4/NF) using a simple hydrothermal method. As shown in Fig. 12 , this heterogeneous structure, composed of nanoparticles and nanoparticles, imparted excellent superhydrophilicity and superaerophobicity to W-MoS2/FeNi2S4/NF. The reduced adhesion force of droplets on the electrode surface and rapid bubble release significantly enhanced electrocatalytic efficiency. Electrochemical performance tests showed that the W-MoS2/FeNi2S4/NF catalyst achieved overpotentials of 92 mV (HER) and 177 mV (OER) at a current density of 10 mA cm-2. These results indicate that the prepared W-MoS2/FeNi2S4/NF provides a more favorable and reasonable direction for the preparation of efficient and inexpensive bifunctional electrocatalysts [133,134]. Compared to monometallic and bimetallic catalysts, there is a synergistic effect between different metals in a polymetallic system, which can produce superior catalytic activity. One metal promotes the adsorption of reactants, while the other metal contributes to the conversion of reaction intermediates. The synergistic effect of these two metals greatly increases the rate of electrocatalytic reactions. Besides, the ability to adsorb and reduce oxygen molecules can be optimized among multiple metals to find the best combination of catalytic properties, thus effectively regulating the catalytic performance. In order to enhance the electrocatalytic OER/HER reaction process, the construction of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic electrocatalytic surfaces is sought, as reported in a recent study. Song and co-workers have constructed in situ arrays of CoFe LDH nanosheets on nickel foam (CoFe LDH NS arrays). The electrodes can be operated stably for 200 h at a high current density of 1000 mA cm-2 with a low overpotential of only 275 mV. The high catalytic activity, mechanical stability, and electrical conductivity can be attributed to the tight interfacial contact between the NF substrate and the NiS interlayer and CoFe LDH. In addition, the unique super-oxygen-phobic surface of the nanosheet arrays facilitates the release of gas bubbles and the recombination of electrolyte with the active sites [135]. In addition, Huang and co-workers prepared a novel heterostructured hierarchical superhydrophilic and superhydrophobic 3D nanorod-like bifunctional catalyst (Ni3S2/VS2) on nickel foam using a simple one-step hydrothermal method as an excellent electrocatalyst for UOR and HER. The underwater bubble contact angle of Ni3S2/VS2 is 151.1°, which is far better than the comparison samples, suggesting that the generated bubbles are capable of the formation of heterogeneous structure can effectively enhance the reaction of Ni3S2/VS2 underwater, which is the most effective way to enhance the reaction of Ni3S2/VS2. The formation of heterogeneous structure can effectively enhance the catalytic activity of nanomaterials for UOR and HER, which provides a feasible solution for the preparation of highly efficient non-precious metal monolithic urea electrocatalysts [136]. Above by constructing nanosheet arrays and conventional heterojunctions enough to form electrocatalyst surfaces with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobicity. This greatly improves the catalytic reaction, and in addition, we can improve the electrocatalytic performance by changing the crystal lattice of the material, changing the capillary pressure inside the material, or changing the electronic structure inside the material by changing the phase transition. 5 Durability of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic electrocatalyst Stability or durability, the ability of catalyst to maintain its initial catalytic activity over a long period of time, is an important parameter for evaluating the suitability of catalyst for industrial applications [137]. The performance of electrocatalysts depends on the structural characteristics and chemical properties of the materials, and it has been shown that highly corrosive and oxidizing anodes can lead to severe deactivation and instability of electrocatalytic materials, in addition to the fact that the stability test itself is carried out in a highly corrosive alkaline electrolyte solution, and under prolonged stability test [138], the instability of the materials will lead to the degradation of electrocatalytic performance, resulting in the decrease of the electrolytic efficiency and the economic loss. The instability of the material will lead to the deterioration of the electrocatalytic performance and the decrease of the electrolysis efficiency, which will lead to the economic loss. This constitutes a major obstacle to the large-scale application of water electrolysis. Therefore, it is necessary to find highly stable OER/HER electrocatalytic materials for industrial applications at high current densities [139]. It has been shown that improving the structural features of the surface of the materials, such as creating materials with double-layered layers of metal hydroxides, surfaces with more exposed active sites, adjusting the electronic structure of the surface, or coating the surface with a protective layer, can improve the stability of the electrocatalytic materials [140], and thus realize the application of electrocatalysts for industrial applications at high current densities. Ni/NiFe-based is abundantly available worldwide and has good mechanical strength and ductility. Sulfide electrocatalysts based on nickel foam, He and co-workers prepared self-supported microporous Ni(OH)x/Ni3S2 heterostructured electrocatalysts (Ni(OH)x/Ni3S2/NF) on nickel foam with superhydrophilic properties through electrochemical processes. When operated at a high current density of about 320 mA cm-2, it only decayed by 1 % for up to 1000 h, indicating its excellent long-term stability to HER at high currents [54]. Meanwhile, on this basis, Liu and co-workers successfully synthesized a heterostructured NiFe-LDH-coated CoS-NiS (NiFe-LDH@CoS-NiS/NF) grown on nickel foam. The layered structure of its electrocatalyst led to abundant heterogeneous junction surfaces, which could enable more active sites to be exposed. The synergistic effect and strong electronic interaction between CoS-NiS and NiFe-LDH can enhance the intrinsic OER activity. And it has excellent stability at high current density of 500 mA cm-2 for >200 h in both alkaline freshwater and alkaline seawater [78]. In addition Ma and co-workers prepared FeCoNiOx/C/NF electrocatalysts by a simple impregnation-foaming-calcination method, and no overpotential decay was observed for 250 h at 500 mA cm-2, indicating that the prepared electrocatalysts exhibited excellent stability exhibited excellent stability [117]. Nickel foam based phosphides showed excellent stability. R. Andaveh and co-workers prepared CoMn/CuNiP/NF heterostructured electrocatalysts by rapid and inexpensive electrochemical deposition, which could be operated stably for 500 h at a current density of 500 mA cm-2, indicating that it has very excellent stability [127]. Meanwhile, Wang and co-workers prepared NiFe-Vo-P electrocatalysts with phosphorylated oxygen vacancies,which could be stably operated for 100 h and 140 h at a current density of 400 mA cm-2 for HER and OER, indicating their excellent stability [101]. The nickel- and nickel-iron based sulfides and phosphides showed excellent stability, which can meet the industrial demand under high current density conditions. 6 Summary This paper provides an overview of the basic mechanisms of electrochemical hydrogen evolution reaction and oxygen evolution reaction, with special emphasis on the application of Ni-based and NiFe-based electrocatalysts with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic properties in water separation. When Ni-based and NiFe-based materials are combined with transition metals, these metals can efficiently modulate the electronic structure to optimize the adsorption and activation of reaction intermediates. In some multimetallic catalysts consisting of transition and noble metals, the d electrons of the transition metal interact with the d electrons of the noble metal, changing the electronic state of the catalyst. This increases the number of active sites for a particular reaction and greatly improves the reactivity. By adjusting the ratio of multiple metals, the combination with the best performance can be found. From the above, it can be concluded that the intermodulation between the metals effectively reduces the overpotential of the electrocatalyst and significantly reduces the Tafel slope of the electrocatalyst. The surface wettability of the catalyst was improved, which effectively reduced the contact angle between the solution and the electrocatalyst, so that the droplets rapidly wetted the electrode surface. It has a higher specific surface energy, thus exhibiting excellent superhydrophilicity and superhydrophobicity, effectively improving the overall water separation efficiency. Based on the knowledge of the theoretical values of contact angle shown in Table 1 , we summarize the electrocatalytic performance characterization of electrocatalysts with superhydrophilic/ superhydrophobicity in recent years. In addition, nickel-based electrocatalysts (including electrocatalysts with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobicity) have long-term stability and corrosion resistance, and can catalyze reactions efficiently in a variety of electrochemical environments. This property enables nickel-based and nickel-iron based materials with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobicity to maintain stable performance during long-term electrocatalytic processes, minimizing the risk of performance degradation or failure. Due to these excellent catalytic properties, nickel-based and nickel-iron based materials with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobicity could facilitate the development and application of water electrolysis for hydrogen production. This paper also describes the application of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic non-nickel-based, non-nickel-iron based, and polymetallic electrocatalytic materials in water separation. The superhydrophilic/ superhydrophobicity of these electrocatalysts can enable the droplets to penetrate into the surface of the materials rapidly and the bubbles to detach in time, avoiding a large accumulation of bubbles, thus exposing more active sites, accelerating the reaction process, improving the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) performances of the electrocatalytic materials, and ultimately realizing the high-efficiency hydrogen production. 7 Outlook Studies on the catalytic performance of electrochemical hydrogen and oxygen precipitation have shown that bubbles generated in the electrolyte often accumulate on the electrode surface and block the active sites, thus significantly reducing the electrochemical efficiency. Therefore, the design and development of electrocatalysts with rough surfaces have become particularly urgent and important. The rough electrode surfaces can be prepared by modulating the electronic structure, doping heteroatoms, and utilizing surface defect engineering. This can effectively enhance the performance of electrocatalysts for hydrogen-extraction reaction (HER) and oxygen-extraction reaction (OER) in the overall water decomposition process. Despite the above progress, there are still some challenges and opportunities that need to be addressed in order to advance the development of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic nickel (Ni)/nickel-iron (NiFe)-based electrocatalysts in the future. (i) Although significant progress has been made in this field, it still does not meet the requirements of industrial applications. Besides to the study of catalyst surfaces with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobicity, further research can be carried out on the internal channels of the three-dimensional network structure. As bubbles generated in the electrolyte pass through the interior of the electrode, they may be affected by factors such as the buoyancy of the water, the capillary pressure inside the electrocatalyst, and the combined forces of the bubbles themselves. These factors determine whether the bubbles can quickly and efficiently pass through the channel and leave the electrode surface, which is an area worth exploring and investigating in the future. (ii) Moreover, it is considered to improve the preparation methods of superhydrophilic/ superhydrophobic electrodes by reactions involving urea and hydrazine. The theoretical decomposition voltage for urea electrolysis is relatively low, typically about 0.37 V. This means that in practice, urea electrolysis may require less electrical energy consumption, which can reduce the cost of hydrogen production. It is also possible to prepare electrocatalysts with superior catalytic properties through a series of reactions with numerous organic functional groups in organic compounds. Furthermore, urea electrolysis causes relatively weak corrosion of electrode materials. Some studies have reported that hydrogels with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic properties can also enhance the electrocatalytic performance, which is a very promising idea. (iii) Nickel- and nickel-iron based electrocatalysts are reported in this paper. The use of violet gum wood, which has its own gas-phobic properties, as a substrate can expose more active sites. However, the exploration of violet gum wood in this area is not deep enough. We can improve the preparation of electrocatalysts with more excellent performance by utilizing violet gum wood as a substrate. As well, we can strengthen the research on copper- and iron-based electrocatalysts. (iv) The morphological structure of the electrocatalyst surface should also be further explored. At present, the morphology of electrocatalysts prepared by hydrothermal method is the best, while the morphology of electrocatalysts prepared by electrodeposition and annealing method is not ideal and rather homogeneous. Therefore, we should explore methods to prepare electrocatalysts with rich and diverse morphologies. Besides, the surface roughness of electrocatalysts needs to be further improved. At present, there are some electrocatalysts that can operate stably at high current densities, which can meet the industrial demand to a certain extent, but the quantity is still too small and there are certain deficiencies, and large-scale industrial applications still need to develop more stable electrocatalysts at a deeper level. Therefore, it is urgent to seek and develop superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic electrocatalysts that can be used in industrial applications at high point current densities. Therefore, there is an urgent need to explore electrocatalysts that can operate at high current densities. Therefore, the preparation of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic electrodes that meet the industrial requirements, are easy to operate and inexpensive remains a major challenge for us. Certainly, it is a worthy goal and direction to pursue. CRediT authorship contribution statement Ruirui Zhang: Writing – original draft, Methodology, Formal analysis, Conceptualization. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen production by water electrolysis is a convenient, low-energy and simple process. The generation of hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) through water electrolysis is a sustainable option for future clean energy, but it still faces challenges. A large number of gas bubbles are constantly generated during the hydrogen production process. These bubbles easily adhere to the surface of the material and cannot be detached from the surface quickly enough in time. Over time, the accumulation of bubbles relentlessly obscures a large number of otherwise active catalytic sites, severely hindering the mass-transfer process of reactants and products and leading to a dramatic decrease in mass-transfer efficiency. This leads to a significant reduction in the hydrogen production efficiency, which in turn reduces the overall efficiency of water decomposition. Therefore, the design and preparation of electrocatalysts with superhydrophilic/superhydrophobicity is one of the techniques to improve droplet wettability and reduce bubble attachment. Due to the ability of the superhydrophilic droplets to spread and penetrate rapidly on the electrode surface, Moreover, the superhydrophobicity greatly reduces the adhesion of gas bubbles on the electrode surface. As a result, the mass transfer and reaction kinetics involved in the hydrogen exclusion reaction (HER) and oxygen exclusion reaction (OER) were significantly optimized, which in turn enhanced the catalytic process of the oxygen exclusion reaction/hydrogen exclusion reaction. This paper reviews the reaction mechanisms of superhydrophilic/superhydrophobic electrocatalysts, as well as the mechanisms of hydrogen and oxygen precipitation. Special attention is given to various preparation strategies for bimetallic nickel-iron based (NiFe-based) electrocatalysts and the application of heteroatom doping, heterostructures and oxygen vacancies in NiFe-based electrocatalysts. In addition, this review discusses the practical applications of other monometallic, bimetallic, and multimetallic electrocatalysts in the field of efficient electrocatalysis, as well as the challenges and future prospects.
